question.text: Consider the following match of hormones and select the incorrect one:

options.text: Cortisol: Anti-inflammatory, immuno-suppressive and stimulate RBC production.
Thyroxine: Regulate <math><mtext>BMR</mtext></math>, maintain water-electrolyte balance and support RBC formation.
Adrenaline: Prepare body for emergency or  <math><mtext>'3 F'</mtext></math>  conditions.
Calcitonin: Decreases bone calcium level in human body.

solution.text: Glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol hormone, produce anti-inflammatory reactions and suppress the immune response. They also stimulate <math><mtext>RBC</mtext></math> production. Adrenaline or epinephrine is secreted from the adrenal medulla in response to stress or emergency or fight, flight and fright conditions. Thyroxine regulates BMR, maintains water-electrolyte balance and supports RBC formation. Thyrocalcitonin (TCT) is a long peptide hormone secreted by parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland (C-cells). Its secretion is regulated by an increased plasma level of calcium by a feedback mechanism. TCT lowers calcium level in the blood to normal by increasing calcium deposition in the bones, so it checks osteoporosis and stimulates excretion of calcium in the urine.
